Patent Information.Abstract: A method is described for treating a microbial infection with a peptide whose amino acid sequence has a formula selected from the group consisting of: (a) B n1 -Z; (b) B n1 -Z-B n2; and (c) Z-B n1 wherein B is a basic amino acid residue; n1 and n2 are 1 to 6; and Z is a sequence of about 11 to about 24 amino acid residues, the sequence having an average hydrophobicity value of at least 0.3, and preferably at least 0.4. These peptides show antimicrobial activity against microorganisms including both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.

Sequence Information.Hemolytic Activity: [Ref.29275987] MHC = 320 μM against human red blood cells. Note:Minimum hemolytic concentration (MHC) is the minimum peptide concentration at which red blood cells undergo > 2% hemolysis.
Sequence Information.Cytotoxicity: No cytotoxicity information found in the reference(s) presented
Sequence Information.Structure Description: As previously reported, 6K-F17 adopts a random coil structure in aqueous buffer and an α helix in the presence of SDS detergent micelles.
Sequence Information.Function: Antibacterial activity against Gram-negative bacteria. No experiments about antibacterial activity against Gram-positive bacteria are recorded.

Literature.Title: Influence of hydrocarbon-stapling on membrane interactions of synthetic antimicrobial peptides
Literature.Author: Tracy A Stone, Gregory B Cole, Huong Q Nguyen, Simon Sharpe, Charles M Deber
